description: From Latin migratus, past participle of migrō (“migrate, change, transport”).

verbs.description: migrate (third-person singular simple present migrates, present participle migrating, simple past and past participle migrated)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To relocate periodically from one region to another, usually according to the seasons.
examples: Twice a year the geese migrate — from Florida to Canada and back again.
Twice a year the Minnesotans migrate from their state to the Gulf of Mexico.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To change one's geographic pattern of habitation.
examples: Many groups had migrated to western Europe from the plains of eastern Europe.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To change habitations across a border; to move from one country or political region to another.
examples: To escape persecution, they migrated to a neutral country.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To move slowly towards, usually in groups.
examples: Once the hosts started bickering in the kitchens, the guests began to migrate towards the living room.

entries.meaning: (transitive, computing): To move computer code or files from one computer or network to another.
examples: They had finished migrating all of the affected code to the production server by 2:00am, three hours later than expected.

entries.meaning: (transitive, marketing) To induce customers to shift purchases from one set of a company's related products to another.
examples: We were hoping to migrate the customers of the "C" series to the "E" series and the "E" customers to the "S" series.
